Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South10th FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2630tamiment.wagner@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-06-14T18:44:49Describing Archives: A Content Standard
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Time's Up Records
Di Paola, Domenic
TAM 522
6 Linear Feet in 5 record cartons and 2 manuscript boxes
1993-2012 Time's Up is a New York City environmentalist organization whose principal activity is the promotion of bicycle riding and the rights of cyclists through its Critical Mass campaigns. This collection consists of photographs, ephemera, and clippings related to Time's Up environmental organizing in New York City. These documents include posters, pamphlets, zines, flyers, and events calendars created to promote Critical Mass demonstrations and other acts of protest, events and celebrations, and fundraisers for Time's Up. They also include several binders containing local articles related to bike safety, the construction of bike lanes, and cycling events.
Materials are in English.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Accruals
Further accruals are expected.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Dominic (Bill) Di Paola on behalf of Time's Up in 2009; additional materials were donated in 2010, 2011, and 2016 The accession numbers associated with this collection are 2009.094, 2010.005, 2010.079, 2011.007, and 2016.026.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. Materials are grouped according to the donations received by the library.
Historical/Biographical Note
Time's Up is a New York City environmentalist organization whose principal activity is the promotion of bicycle riding and the rights of cyclists through its Critical Mass campaigns.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Time's Up Records; TAM 522; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning, materials were transferred into archival boxes and described on the collection-level No arrangement or other physical interventions have taken place. Inventories from the 2009, 2010, and 2011 donations were provided by the donor.
Scope and Content Note
This collection consists of materials created and collected by Time's Up in the course of their environmental activism. Materials includes posters, pamphlets, zines, flyers, and event calendars created to promote the organization's events and fundraisers, with particular emphasis on Critical Mass demonstrations and other acts of protest. The collection also includes several binders containing local articles related to bike safety, the construction of bike lanes, and cycling events.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Time's Up was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

Time's Up bicycle repair workshops, one of Simon teaching at Time's Up's Brooklyn space, and two of Susan teaching women-only class in Time's Up's Manhattan Space.
2 Calendars: Monthly calendars including garden clean-ups, bicycle rides, educational workshops, bike rides. Helped create new riders, eventually had enough bike riders to put pressure on the city for safer, greener infrastructure.

3 Lawsuits
Supreme Court New York State, plaintiffs; against Time's Up, defendants.
United States District Court, Rebecca BRAY, plaintiffs; against New-York City
Legal folders containing press releases, letter from the City of New York Police Department to Time's Up threatening to ticket or arrest bicyclists
New York Times article backed up with photographs from Time's Up of the police caught stealing bicycles. This incident then became the Bray case. Time's Up provided evidence that the city was harassing and taking people's bicycles to deter the growth of cycling during a crucial period.

Scope and Content Note
This donation consists of ten binders of clippings related to Time's Up activities in New York City.The binders are grouped by year, and contain articles from local New York City publications like the Village Voice, Time Out New York, and the New York Times about events and news related to environmental issues in the city. The bulk of the articles relate to bike safety, construction of bike lanes, Critical Mass demonstrations, and cycling events.
